You left out a key word -- EARLY. Also, there is no such thing as the stock price being too high. Essentially, the notes cannot be redeemed for cash earlier than the 5 year maturity unless the stock price exceeds $18.187 for the designated time period and other conditions. Or expressing it the other way around, the notes can be redeemed as early as Oct. 5, 2027, for cash if the stock price exceeds that price threshhold. Otherwise, the holders of the notes are entitled to hold them for the full five years and then the notes will be payable in cash with the option for the company to pay in unregistered shares if it chooses.

The following long sentence deal PR, means that PGY can redeem the notes for cash only if the stock price is too high (130% of 13.99$) for certain period of time , and with some other unspecified conditions. Is my understanding correct? "The notes will not be redeemable prior to October 5, 2027. The notes will be redeemable, in whole or in part (subject to certain limitations on partial redemptions), for cash at the option of Pagaya US at any time, and from time to time, on or after October 5, 2027 and on or before the 41st scheduled trading day immediately before the maturity date, but only if the last reported sale price per Class A ordinary share of Pagaya exceeds 130% of the exchange price for a specified period of time and certain other conditions are satisfied."

Yes. The deal is done. It is unlikely that the notes will ever be redeemed for unregistered shares. However, even if they are, there is no book value dilution as the exchange price is based on $13.99 which is 45% above yesterday's closing price and redemption is limited at times unless the stock price is 130% above that.  Time to buy all you can unless the price jumps too much after investors digest the full terms of the deal.

Mr Market is very emotional and always over-reacts.  If you think this move makes good business sense (which I do) then you are grateful for the buying opportunity and go in deeper.  I can‚Äôt see anything wrong with what they did and think this is just part of the growing pains of being a relatively young company that isn‚Äôt yet able to self fund their available growth.

Logically, I know their moves are financially good (PR-wise, maybe not so much), that they strike excellent deals and doing all the right things to become GAAP profitable, which - if and when happens - will be a huge turning point for them as they will be able to sign more and more deals without incurring debt, causing the stock to skyrocket. Typically, these types of events take 3 days before the stock bounces back.  However, the volume today was an all time record for this stock, which wasn't overbought to begin with.  And the news is not devastating like a massive dilution.  It's taking on exchangeable debt that unlike a convertible debt is under the control of the company as to how much they payback with cash and how much with stock for the next 3 years.  This gives them much-needed flexibility to manage their cash flows, some breathing space, if you will, to expand the network.  You see, the problem is their margins are so thin, they have to make up for it in volume.  But to scale up, they must retain more and more (in terms of dollars) on their balance sheet, which right now, they have to borrow, which cuts into their margins.  So they need some flexibility in financing which puts them in a much better position in ramping up the volume, without diluting shares in the near-term, if at all.  This exchangeable debt does that.  The market over-reacted to the news as if it was an immediate stock dilution.  Perfect opportunity to buy in.  Tomorrow morning may see some further downdraft.  Hoping it goes below $9 so I can buy some more.  Might churn throughout the day at lower volume but by Monday, should see a bounce back.

Hard to believe the market misunderstands the note issuance to this large an extent.  This stock has traded over 25% of its share float and the day hasn't ended.  This is essentially just a routine note issue with an extremely unlikely possibility of a per share accounting dilution 5 years from now with no shares added to the float no matter what.  It just gives the company an automatic "escape route" in the event it doesn't happen to have free cash to repay the notes when they come due which is a benefit for the company.  As it continues to issue larger and larger ABS deals and it has to keep some participation (although it has managed to lower its percentage), it is required to keep certain reserves on hand.  This is just part of the ordinary increase in those required reserves.  It even provides an automatic resolution if it doesn't happen to have sufficient free cash on the due date so there is no possiblity of any default.

Well‚Ä¶that‚Äôs great‚Ä¶still dropped almost $3 though and as investors, it comes down to share price being the ultimate and most important number.

Shares at these prices are an absolute steal for one of the largest if not the largest company providing AI software to boost the amount of loans approved for customers of various businesses along with a remarkable track record of lowering loss ratios on those loans.  That allows it to be able to package those loans into ABS and issue them while it collects fees on both ends of the financing.  With great demand, it has reduced its own money in each deal which lowers the risk to PGY and provides a third source of income. Today's reaction is overdone by those who fail to understand that the new notes are essentially designed to prevent any dilution.  It is likely no shares will ever be issued.  The company controls whether it pays the debt in shares and those shares are not eligible to be listed for trading in the public market.  Private purchasers of this debt must have full confidence in getting paid back.  Otherwise, they would not invest but they are prepared to accept payment in non-tradeable shares if the company chooses to pay them off that way.  If it does not have the cash or ability to place more debt at that time, it insures there is no possibility of an actual default.  If shares were issued, the company would have a plan to redeem them at some point as the holders have no practical way to sell them except to another private buyer.  Ultimately, there is no dilution to the float of its shares.  Any "dilution" for accounting purposes would be temporary and minimal.

Investors have ignored the clear statement on the debt offering and the trading in the thin off hours is mistaken.  There is no dilution and will be no dilution to the float on the market:  "The offer and sale of the notes, the guarantee and any Class A ordinary shares of Pagaya deliverable upon exchange of the notes HAVE NOT BEEN, AND WILL NOT BE,  registered under the Securities Act or any other securities laws, and the notes and any such shares cannot be offered or sold except pursuant to an exemption from, or in a transaction not subject to, the registration requirements of the Securities Act and any other applicable securities laws."  (emphasis added by me).  Obviously, it is clear that the notes are intended to be paid off in cash but just in case, there is a provision to allow payment in unregistered shares that cannot be sold in the public market but would either have to be sold to other qualifed private buyers or the company would end up buying them back at some delayed date.  The shares could never be dumped on the market.
